columns.text: In this problem, we will determine whether it is beneficial for the firm to subscribe to the given policy based on the information provided.

In order to solve for the total revenue for the policy, we will first identify how many items will be sold. As stated in the problem, $4\%$ of the bicycles will be sold through a credit agency. Therefore, we will take $4\%$ of the original $125$ bicycles.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Quantity sold}&=125 \times 0.04\\[15 pt]
&=5
\end{aligned}$$

This means that there will be $5$ bikes sold through a credit agency.

From this quantity, we can multiply the price to get the total revenue:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total revenue}&=5 \times \$750\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,750
\end{aligned}$$

The total revenue for the policy is $\$3,750$

Next, we will solve for the cost. The total cost of this can be solved by multiplying the variable cost to the total number of bicycles then adding the initial charge. Take note that the quantity that we will use for this is the total number of bicycles since even if we do not take this policy, the cost will still be the same since we already paid for all the bicycles. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total cost}&=(\$8.95 \times 125)+\$1,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,118.75
\end{aligned}$$

The total cost for this is $\$2,118.75$

Now that we have the revenue and the cost, we can solve for the net present value by subtracting the cost from the revenue.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\$3,750-\$2,118.75\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,631.25
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of the policy is $\$1,631.25$ which means that the firm should subscribe to the policy of this agency since the value obtained is positive.
